Background Data

In accordance with Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations Chapter 68 (40 CFR 68) promulgated by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), Sara Lee Foods submits this Risk Management Plan (RMP) for operations at their Chicago, Illinois facility.  Sara Lee Foods - Chicago Facility?s operations include the processing of meat products (Kosher meats) for public consumption.  The SIC for Sara Lee Foods -Chicago Facility is 2013 and the NAICS code is 311612.  Sara Lee Foods - Chicago Facility has been in operation at this location for over 30 years, providing quality meat products and over 300 jobs to the local community.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policy

Sara Lee Foods - Chicago Facility is committed to protecting the health of its employees, the surrounding community, and the environment; therefore it is Sara Lee Foods - Chicago Facility?s policy to maintain compliance with 40 CFR 68 as well as Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) regulations promulgated as Title 29 of the Code of Federal Regulations, Chapter 1910, Section 119 (29 CFR 1910.119), and OSHA?s Hazardous Operations and Emergency Response regulations (29 CFR 1910.120).

Stationary Sources and Regulated Substances

Sara Lee Foods - Chicago Facility is required to maintain low temperatures in the food processing areas of the plant that are within standards required by the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) to ensure quality in the final products.  Sara Lee Foods - Chicago Facility uses anhydrous ammonia as a refrigerant.  Anhydrous ammonia is the RMP regulated chemical.  Sara Lee Foods - Chicago Facility?s refrigeration system consists of receivers, compressors, evaporators, condensers, re-circulators, and piping.  This process is a Program 3 process as defined by the risk management program rule (40 CFR Part 68).

Release Scenario

In accordance with 40 CFR Subpart B, Sara Lee Foods evaluated off-site

consequences for releases of anhydrous ammonia.  Both a worst-case scenario and an alternate case scenario were developed.
 

Accidental Release Prevention Program

The ammonia refrigeration system is designed and constructed in accordance with ANSI/IIAR 2-1992 Standard for Equipment, Design, and Installation of Ammonia Mechanical Refrigerating Systems.  To prevent and mitigate accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia, Sara Lee Foods - Chicago Facility has implemented several precautionary measures, such as process/equipment controls, standard operating procedures, preventive maintenance programs, employee training, and audit programs.  

Sara Lee Foods - Chicago Facility has implemented and is compliance with OSHA?s PSM regulations and as such, has evaluated and engineered for unintended anhydrous ammonia releases.  Controls installed to prevent catastrophic releases of ammonia include both process equipment (vents, pressure relief valves, backup pumps, and manual shutoffs) and automated controls (automatic shut-offs, ammonia leak detection system, and electrical distribution system grounding).

Sara Lee Foods - Chicago Facility has made several modifications to its existing refrigeration system.  Upgrades include the facility?s relief valves located on the roof; the facility?s ventilation in the engine room; and the insulation of its roofing pipes for enhanced protection from corrosion.

Sara Lee Foods - Chicago Facility has developed safety measures as part of its standard operating procedures for all employees and contractors that have contact with the ammonia refrigeration system.   These safety procedures were developed by Original Equipment Manufacturers (OEM) and refrigeration system operators and are reviewed on a periodic basis.  Process safety information for the refrigeration system is reviewed during PSM/RMP meetings as well.  Sara Lee Foods - Chicago Facility encourages employee participation in development of the control measures used at the plant by

means of verbal discussion and training sessions.  Written management of change procedures have also been established. 

Sara Lee Foods - Chicago Facility understands that maintaining the refrigeration system in good working order is essential to preventing accidental releases; therefore Sara Lee Foods - Chicago Facility has implemented a preventative maintenance program.  The preventative maintenance program is scheduled, documented and managed using an equipment log attached to each major piece of equipment to ensure that regular maintenance occurs.  Also, infrared testing is conducted on an annual basis to ensure the mechanical integrity of critical refrigeration system components.

Finally, regularly scheduled audits are performed on the ammonia refrigeration system to ensure that Sara Lee Foods - Chicago Facility?s control measures are effective in maintaining the safe operation of the plant.
 

In accordance with the PSM program, Sara Lee Foods - Chicago Facility conducts detailed PSM compliance audits at least once every three years.  Each audit incorporates review of process safety information, process hazard analysis, operating procedures, training programs, system mechanical integrity, management of change, pre-start up review procedures, compliance audit procedures, incident investigation procedures, employee participation programs, hot work permit procedures, and contractor safety procedures.

? In addition, Sara Lee Foods - Chicago Facility is audited by the local fire department on an annual basis.

? Sara Lee Foods - Chicago Facility is audited by the USDA/OSHA on a periodic basis.

? Sara Lee Foods - Chicago Facility?s insurance carrier also conducts independent audits on an annual basis.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

While ammonia refrigeration is a mature industry employing known technology, the plant remains abreast of current innovations that improve safety.  To this end, the Sara Lee Corporation is an active member of International Instit

ute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) and the Refrigeration Engineers Training Association (RETA).  This involvement enables the facility to learn and implement the most modern safety system improvements as they emerge within the ammonia refrigeration industry.  The Sara Lee Foods - Chicago Facility is planning to implement a maintenance management system to enhance reliable operation of the RMP covered process and has scheduled the installation of a computer program to enable safer equipment operations.

Five-Year Accident History

Over the last five years, Sara Lee Foods - Chicago Facility has not experienced an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia from the ammonia refrigeration system causing any on-site death, injury or significant property damage, or known off-site death, injury, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place.

Emergency Response Program

The City of Chicago Fire Department, Hazardous Material Division has employees trained to respond to an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia.  Sara Lee Foods - Chicago Facility has a documented evacuation procedures (Policy# 301 A & C) located in the Emergency Plan & Response manual (located on the RMP shelf in the Safety & Environmental Manger?s office) in order to facilitate response efforts in the event of an off-site anhydrous ammonia release.  Notification to the City of Chicago Fire Department, Hazardous Material Division is one measure included in the Evacuation Plan.
 

To assure that the local governmental response agencies are familiar with Sara Lee Foods - Chicago Facility?s operations, the facility has submitted copies of the Plan for review and approval by the local agencies.  The following local agencies have reviewed and approved Sara Lee Foods - Chicago Facility?s Plan:

? National Response Center

? Illinois Emergency Management Agency

? Cook County Sheriff?s Emergency Management Agency

? City of Chicago, Office of the Emergency Preparedness Disaster Service

In addition to the above local response agencies, Sara Lee Foods - Chicago Facility has arranged emergency response assistance with City of Chicago, Fire Department, Office of Preparedness Disaster Service.

In the event of an anhydrous ammonia release with off-site effects, the general public will be warned using one or more of the following methods:

? City of Chicago Police and Fire Department fire vehicles equipped with public address systems, and 

? Public notification of residents

As a safeguard measure, Sara Lee Foods - Chicago Facility has arranged for back-up assistance from local environmental clean-up contractor(s).
